windTurbineMKCV

Class Coefficients

  • java.lang.Object
    • windTurbineMKCV.Coefficients

  • public class Coefficients
extends java.lang.Object
    This class contains methods used to calculate the aerodynamic coefficients of drag and lift. The airfoil model used is a NACA 2412 (naca2412-il) with RE=200,000 and Ncrit=9.
    Version:
    05/15/2016
    Author:
    Mitchell Keeley, Chaitanya Varier

    • Method Detail

      • getCoefficientLift

        public static double getCoefficientLift(double alpha)
        Returns the lift coefficient of the airfoil as a function of the angle of attack in radians. This is the curve-fitted representation of the extended polar. The extended polar was generated by extrapolating the data taken from the xFoil predicted polar for the airfoil under the given aerodynamic constraints using the Viterna method to extend the alpha range from -pi to pi radians.

        The mathematical representation of this method is a piecewise function consisting of a sum of sines and cosines generated through Fourier transform when

        -0.196349541 rad < alpha <= -0.161442956 rad, when
        -0.161442956 rad < alpha <= 0 rad, when
        0 rad < alpha <= 0.23536 rad, when
        0.2487090 rad < alpha <= 0.296706 rad, and when
        2.558 rad < alpha <= pi rad.

        The function consists of polynomial terms when

        -pi rad <= alpha <= -0.196349541 rad, when
        0.23536 rad < alpha <= 0.248709 rad, and when
        0.296706 rad < alpha <= 2.558 rad.
        Parameters:
        alpha - Angle of attack in radians (any real angle).
        Returns:
        Coefficient of lift as function of angle alpha.

      • getCoefficientDrag

        public static double getCoefficientDrag(double alpha)
        Returns the drag coefficient of the airfoil as a function of the angle of attack in radians. This is the curve-fitted representation of the extended polar. The extended polar was generated by extrapolating the data taken from the xFoil predicted polar for the airfoil under the given aerodynamic constraints using the Viterna method to extend the alpha range from -pi to pi radians. The mathematical representation of this method is a piecewise function consisting of a sum of sines and cosines generated through Fourier transform when

        -pi rad <= alpha < -0.196350 rad, and when
        0.349066 rad < alpha <= pi rad.

        The function consists of polynomial terms when

        -0.196350 rad <= alpha <= 0.349066 rad.
        Parameters:
        alpha - Angle of attack in radians (any real angle).
        alpha - Angle of attack in radians (any real angle).
        Returns:
        Coefficient of lift as function of angle alpha.
